text.p: Singaporean software company Creative Technolgy Ltd eased Tuesday after it reported earnings in line with expectations.
Creative's American Depositary Receipts (ADRs) were off 7/8 to 20-5/8 in heavy trade. The ADRs were among the most-active issues on the Nasdaq exchange.
After markets closed Monday, Creative reported fourth-quarter earnings per share of $0.55 against a loss of $0.43 for the same period a year before. Its fiscal year profit was $167 million.
Israeli drugs company Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd was off two to 59-3/4 in heavy trade.

Although traders said there was no news prompting the fall, an analyst who asked to remain anonymous said the drop might be sparked by the prospect of lower-than-expected sales for Teva's Copaxone multiple sclerosis drug.

Among Latin American ADRs, Brazilian telecommunications holding Telebras SA rose 2-3/4 to 152-1/8. The rise came after the company said it would distribute shares to subscribers who bought phone lines last year, reversing a decision to pay them in cash.
Because of the decision, Smith Barney telecommunications analyst Peter Treadway cut his second-quarter earnings per ADR estimate to $2.41 from $2.64.

Japanese electronics giant Sony Corp rose three to 100-3/4, above a 12-month closing high, in heavy trade. Traders have said the shares in part were riding hopes that first quarter earnings due out Thursday would be strong.
Decliners led advancers 277 to 197 among 814 ADRs. The ADR group was off 0.12 percent and volume in late morning was 31.5 million ADRs. ADRs allow U.S. trade of foreign shares.
